About Our Work

This is a semantic layout to showcase best practices with CSS, HTML, Accessibility, and vanilla Javascript.

Accessibility
Standards

Website accessibility best practices ensure that digital content is usable by everyone, including individuals with disabilities. Key practices include using semantic HTML elements, such as headings and landmarks, to create a logical content structure that is easy to navigate with assistive technologies.

Providing alternative text for images ensures that visual content is accessible to screen reader users, while ensuring sufficient color contrast and avoiding color as the sole means of conveying information supports those with visual impairments.

  • Auditory
  • Cognitive
  • Neurological
  • Physical

CSS
Thinking

CSS best practices help ensure maintainable, scalable, and performant styles for web development. Writing clear, consistent, and modular CSS starts with using meaningful class names that follow a naming convention like BEM (Block-Element-Modifier) to improve readability and avoid conflicts.

Keeping CSS organized by grouping related styles, using comments for documentation, and maintaining a consistent structure reduces complexity. Leverage reusable variables for colors, typography, and spacing to enable theme consistency and simplify future changes.

  • Specificity
  • BEM
  • Modular
  • Performant

Vanilla
Javascript

Vanilla JavaScript best practices focus on writing clean, efficient, and maintainable code without relying on frameworks. Start by structuring your code using modular patterns or ES6 modules to separate concerns and improve reusability. Follow consistent naming conventions for variables and functions, and write descriptive comments to enhance readability.

Add event listeners sparingly and clean them up when no longer needed to prevent memory leaks. For accessibility, ensure custom interactions work seamlessly with the keyboard and assistive technologies, and use semantic HTML whenever possible.

  • Modular Design
  • Clean Code
  • Accessibility
